title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the average fixed cost as $25 and/or does not show the work.

AFC= TFC Q = $50 2 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@445E@

The response calculates the average fixed cost as $25 and shows the work.

AFC= TFC Q = $50 2 =$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@445E@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 9 units and/or does not explain that the 9th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($140) is greater than the marginal cost ($125); the firm will not produce the 10th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($145) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($140).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 9 units and explains that the 9th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($140) is greater than the marginal cost ($125); the firm will not produce the 10th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($145) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($140).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the economic profit as $695 and/or does not show the work.

Economic Profit=TR−TC=9( $140 )−$565=$695 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@56F2@

The response calculates the economic profit as $695 and shows the work.

Economic Profit=TR−TC=9( $140 )−$565=$695 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@56F2@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will increase and/or does not explain that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will increase and explains that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will decrease and/or does not explain that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.
The response states that the market price will decrease and explains that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for desk lamps will increase and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for desk lamps with respect to the price of Good H means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good H will lead to an increase in the demand for desk lamps.

The response states that that the demand for desk lamps will increase and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for desk lamps with respect to the price of Good H means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good H will lead to an increase in the demand for desk lamps.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that consumer surplus will decrease and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing consumer surplus.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good H will decrease and explains that an increase in variable cost will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does one of the following:

· States that consumer surplus will decrease and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing consumer surplus.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good H will decrease and explains that an increase in variable cost will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

The response does both of the following:

· States that consumer surplus will decrease and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing consumer surplus.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good H will decrease and explains that an increase in variable cost will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.
